title: 113_hr3202
content: The Act titled "Essential Transportation Worker Identification Credential Assessment Act" requires a comprehensive security assessment of the Transportation Security Card Program. The Secretary of Homeland Security must provide a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security for regulated facilities and vessels. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program's effectiveness in enhancing security and reducing risks for regulated facilities and vessels. The assessment will be carried out by a national laboratory or a maritime security university-based center within the Department of Homeland Security network. The comprehensive assessment of the transportation security card program will be conducted by a national laboratory or maritime security university-based center within the Department of Homeland Security network. It will evaluate the program's effectiveness in addressing security risks, addressing deficiencies identified by the Comptroller General, and conducting a cost-benefit analysis. The evaluation of the transportation security card program will assess its response to security risks, address identified deficiencies, and include a cost-benefit analysis. The Secretary will submit a corrective action plan to relevant committees within 60 days of the assessment. The Secretary will submit a corrective action plan within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program to address security risks, deficiencies, and include program reforms, regulations revisions, and legislative proposals for consideration in rule making. The Secretary will submit a corrective action plan within 60 days of assessing the transportation security card program to address security risks, deficiencies, and include program reforms, regulations revisions, and legislative proposals for consideration in rule making. The plan will be reviewed by the Comptroller General within 120 days to assess the implementation of recommendations. The Comptroller General will review the corrective action plan for the transportation security card program within 120 days to assess the implementation of recommendations from national laboratories, maritime security centers, and previous Comptroller General recommendations. The Secretary of Homeland Security must review and implement recommendations from national laboratories, maritime security centers, and the Comptroller General for the transportation security card program. The Secretary is required to inform specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate about the plan's responsiveness to these recommendations. The Secretary of Homeland Security must review and implement recommendations for the transportation security card program from various entities. The Secretary is required to inform specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate about the plan's responsiveness to these recommendations before issuing a final rule on transportation security card readers. The final rule mandates the use of transportation security card readers until the Comptroller General confirms responsiveness to recommendations and the Secretary updates the list of compatible readers. The final rule requires the use of transportation security card readers until confirmed by the Comptroller General and updated by the Secretary. This does not apply to the TWIC-Reader Requirements rule issued by the Coast Guard in 2013. The final rule mandates the use of transportation security card readers until approved by the Comptroller General and updated by the Secretary. This exemption does not apply to the TWIC-Reader Requirements rule issued by the Coast Guard in 2013. The Comptroller General will provide oversight to the Committee on Homeland Security every six months for three years following the corrective action plan issuance. The Comptroller General will report to relevant committees every six months for three years on the implementation of the corrective action plan issued 18 months after the final rule on transportation security card readers. SEC. 3. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. No extra funds are authorized for this Act and its amendments. Existing funds will be used for implementation.
